title: WELCOME PAGE
text:
1 Welcome to my practicals website!!
Feel at home. This is the introduction page of my site for the practicals.

title: 2  Practical One
text:
3 Question 1
Airquality (available in R) was utilised for this question. Here is a sneak peak of the dataset:


Code
quality_data = airquality
head(quality_data)


  Ozone Solar.R Wind Temp Month Day
1    41     190  7.4   67     5   1
2    36     118  8.0   72     5   2
3    12     149 12.6   74     5   3
4    18     313 11.5   62     5   4
5    NA      NA 14.3   56     5   5
6    28      NA 14.9   66     5   6


The data consists of Ozone, Solar.R, Wind, Temp, Month, and Day columns.


Code
quality_data = airquality
head(quality_data[(is.na(quality_data$Ozone) | is.na(quality_data$Temp)),])


   Ozone Solar.R Wind Temp Month Day
5     NA      NA 14.3   56     5   5
10    NA     194  8.6   69     5  10
25    NA      66 16.6   57     5  25
26    NA     266 14.9   58     5  26
27    NA      NA  8.0   57     5  27
32    NA     286  8.6   78     6   1


Code
tail(quality_data[(is.na(quality_data$Ozone) | is.na(quality_data$Temp)),])


    Ozone Solar.R Wind Temp Month Day
102    NA     222  8.6   92     8  10
103    NA     137 11.5   86     8  11
107    NA      64 11.5   79     8  15
115    NA     255 12.6   75     8  23
119    NA     153  5.7   88     8  27
150    NA     145 13.2   77     9  27




4 Question 2
The following statistics: mean, sd, min, and max were derived for each of temperature and ozone level, and they are as follows:


Code
temp_info = data.frame("Mean" = mean(quality_data$Temp),
                       "Sd" = sd(quality_data$Temp), 
                       "Min" = min(quality_data$Temp), 
                       "Max" = max(quality_data$Temp))
temp_info


      Mean      Sd Min Max
1 77.88235 9.46527  56  97


However, the Ozone column has a few rows with missing data(NAs):


Code
cat("[OUTPUT] Number of missing values for Ozone column:","\t", sum(is.na(quality_data$Ozone)))


[OUTPUT] Number of missing values for Ozone column:      37


So a slight adjustment was made to the code to find the missing values. Please select the Code button below to see the slight adjustment. However, here are the statistics:


Code
Ozone_info = data.frame("Mean" = mean(quality_data$Ozone, na.rm = T),
                       "Sd" = sd(quality_data$Ozone, na.rm = T), 
                       "Min" = min(quality_data$Ozone, na.rm = T), 
                       "Max" = max(quality_data$Ozone, na.rm = T))

Ozone_info


      Mean       Sd Min Max
1 42.12931 32.98788   1 168




5 Question 3
Now we move to a different dataset called Cars available in R. Here is a sneak peak of the data:


Code
cars_data = cars
head(cars_data)


  speed dist
1     4    2
2     4   10
3     7    4
4     7   22
5     8   16
6     9   10


In this section we wanted to, from first principle or Using matrix calculations, find linear regression beta estimates, t-statistics, r squared, standard errors, etc, and fortunately we found the following:


Code
x = cbind(1,cars_data$speed)
y = cars_data$dist
beta_ests = (solve(t(x)%*%x))%*%t(x)%*%y
cars_data = cars
y_hat = x%*%beta_ests
rss = (y - y_hat)^2 |> sum() # Residual Sum of Squares
tss = (y - mean(y))^2 |> sum()   # Total Sum of Squares
r_squared = (tss - rss)/ tss
n = length(y)  # Number of observations
p = ncol(x)    # Number of pars including intercept
residual_variance = rss / (n -p)  # Estimate of residual variance
covariance_matrix = residual_variance*solve(t(x) %*% x)
standard_errors = sqrt(diag(covariance_matrix))
t_stats = beta_ests / standard_errors
p_values = 2 *(1 - pt(abs(t_stats), df = n -p ))
list(
  Betas_estimates = beta_ests,
  RSS = rss,
  R_squared = r_squared,
  Standard_errors = standard_errors,
  P_values = p_values,
  T_statistics = t_stats
)


$Betas_estimates
           [,1]
[1,] -17.579095
[2,]   3.932409

$RSS
[1] 11353.52

$R_squared
[1] 0.6510794

$Standard_errors
[1] 6.7584402 0.4155128

$P_values
             [,1]
[1,] 1.231882e-02
[2,] 1.489919e-12

$T_statistics
          [,1]
[1,] -2.601058
[2,]  9.463990




6 Question 4
Now we use lm() function in R to fit the same data and evaluate whether the estimates from the model are consistent with our first principles or not:


Code
# Use lm directly
model = lm(dist ~ speed, data = cars_data)
summary(model)



Call:
lm(formula = dist ~ speed, data = cars_data)

Residuals:
    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
-29.069  -9.525  -2.272   9.215  43.201 

Coefficients:
            Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept) -17.5791     6.7584  -2.601   0.0123 *  
speed         3.9324     0.4155   9.464 1.49e-12 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 15.38 on 48 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.6511,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.6438 
F-statistic: 89.57 on 1 and 48 DF,  p-value: 1.49e-12


As you can see, the results are quite the same. Thank God!! We are so smart! Interpretation: As speed increases by one unit, distance to stop increases by 3.932 (holding everything else constant).

6 Question 2
Under this code, is the same code rewritten using dplyr and pipe:

flight1 <- flights[flights$month == 1, ]
carrier_vec <- unique(flight1$carrier)
carrier_dist_vec_mean <- numeric(length(carrier_vec))
carrier_dist_vec_sd <- numeric(length(carrier_vec))
for (i in seq_along(carrier_vec)) {
  carrier_dist_vec_mean[i] <- mean(
    flight1$distance[flight1$carrier == carrier_vec[i]]
   )
  carrier_dist_vec_sd[i] <- sd(
    flight1$distance[flight1$carrier == carrier_vec[i]]
  )
}
dist_tbl <- tibble(
  carrier = carrier_vec,
  mean_distance = carrier_dist_vec_mean,
  sd_distance = carrier_dist_vec_sd
)
dist_tbl[order(dist_tbl$mean_distance), ]

# A tibble: 16 × 3
   carrier mean_distance sd_distance
   <chr>           <dbl>       <dbl>
 1 YV               229          0  
 2 9E               476.       334. 
 3 EV               522.       294. 
 4 US               536.       553. 
 5 MQ               566.       223. 
 6 FL               691.       142. 
 7 OO               733         NA  
 8 WN               942.       496. 
 9 B6              1062.       681. 
10 DL              1220.       644. 
11 AA              1350.       626. 
12 UA              1462.       778. 
13 F9              1620          0  
14 AS              2402          0  
15 VX              2495.        98.2
16 HA              4983          0  



flights1 = flights |> filter(month == 1)
carrier_vec = flights |> distinct(carrier) |> pull()
carrier_dist_vec_mean <- carrier_vec |> length() |> numeric()
carrier_dist_vec_sd <- carrier_vec |> length() |> numeric()   


for (i in carrier_vec |> seq_along()){
  carrier_dist_vec_mean[i] = flights1 |>
    filter(carrier == carrier_vec[i]) |> 
    pull(distance) |> mean()
  carrier_dist_vec_sd[i] = flights |> filter(carrier == carrier_vec[i]) |>
    pull(distance) |> sd()
}

dist_tbl <- tibble(
  carrier = carrier_vec,
  mean_distance = carrier_dist_vec_mean,
  sd_distance = carrier_dist_vec_sd
)

dist_tbl |> arrange(mean_distance)

7 Question 3


8 Question 4

flights |> group_by(month, carrier) |>

  pivot_wider(
              names_from = "carrier",
              values_from = "avg_dep_delay"
              )

10 Question 6

flights |> group_by(origin,dest) |>
  summarise(more_than_one = n_distinct(carrier)) |>
  filter(more_than_one > 1)

c.

flights_c = flights |> group_by(origin,dest, carrier) |>
  summarise(avg_arr_delay = mean(arr_delay,na.rm = T)) |>
  left_join(airlines, by = "carrier") |>
  select(origin, dest, carrier, name, avg_arr_delay)

the `.groups` argument.

d.

best_worst_airlines = flights_c |>
  group_by(origin, dest) |>
  summarise(
    best_airline = name[which.min(avg_arr_delay)],
    best_delay = min(avg_arr_delay),
    worst_airline = name[which.max(avg_arr_delay)],
    worst_delay = max(avg_arr_delay),
    .groups = "drop"
  )
